Description: Participants are not yet being recruited or enrolled
Participants are currently being recruited and enrolled
The study has concluded normally; participants are no longer being examined or treated (i.e., last patient's last visit has occurred)
Recruiting or enrolling participants has halted prematurely but potentially will resume
Recruiting or enrolling participants has halted prematurely and will not resume; participants are no longer being examined or treated
Study halted prematurely, prior to enrollment of first participant
Participant has been contacted via email to participate in study.
Participant has been contacted via phone to participate in study.
Participant has been contacted face-to-face to participate in study.
Participant has been contacted via letter to participate in study.
Participant has signed informed consent forms.  Participant has not been enrolled in study.
Participant has been consented and has met eligibility criteria for study.
Participant has completed study and is no longer receiving treatment/s or services.
Participant has been removed from study.(include notes field for reason/description) .
The beginning of the informed consent process.
In-depth informed consent discussion where procedures are performed per protocol. (synthesized)
The period between screening visit and randomization visit.
The method for determining which study design arm the subject is assigned to.
The subject did not meet all inclusion/exclusion criteria after signing consent.
Visit which occurs between protocol-specified visits which can be requested by the investigator, sponsor or subject (synthesized).
Participant is not interested in "XYZ" study
Participant did not meet study criteria
Participant is not interested in participating in research at all
A person identifying with the male sex or gender
A person identifying with the female sex or gender
A person of Cuban, Mexican, Puerto Rican, South or Central American, or other Spanish culture or origin, regardless of race. The term "Spanish origin" can be used in addition to "Hispanic or Latino."
A person NOT of Cuban, Mexican, Puerto Rican, South or Central American, or other Spanish culture or origin, regardless of race.
A person having origins in any of the original peoples of North and South America (including Central America), and who maintains tribal affiliation or community attachment.

A person having origins in any of the original peoples of the Far East, Southeast Asia, or the Indian subcontinent including, for example, Cambodia, China, India, Japan, Korea, Malaysia, Pakistan, the Philippine Islands, Thailand, and Vietnam.
A person having origins in any of the black racial groups of Africa. Terms such as "Haitian," "Dominican," or "Somali" can be used in addition to "Black or African American."
A person having origins in any of the original peoples of Hawaii, Guam, Samoa, or other Pacific Islands.
A person having origins in any of the original peoples of Europe, the Middle East, or North Africa.

(OMB does not support using a multiracial category. However, our field experience has shown that the use of this category is necessary when checking off more than one response option is not possible for a variety of reasons.)
(This category is an indication that the person could not respond to the question and can be asked again during the same visit or during a subsequent visit.)
(This category is an indication that the person did NOT want to respond to the question and should not be asked again during the same visit or during a subsequent visit.)
